Comment: >What in the 1st amendment gives the reporters the right to be in the White House?  Nothing.  What they do have the right to is not to be punished for the content of their reporting, and this is well established in case law.  They were already a part of the press pool, and were removed specifically because their reporting upset the White House when the AP called it the Gulf of Mexico when Trump didn't want them to.  There are two scenarios to look at here:  1) Trump and the administration kicks the AP out because they want it called the Gulf of America and were angry that the AP wasn't obeying their demands.  2) Trump and the administration kicks the AP out because they want to fill their position with Buntluva69420 from the WeedNewz blog because it would "increase reporting diversity."  The first one is unconstitutional because it violates their First Amendment rights by punishing them for the content of their reporting.  The second one is not unconstitutional because it is a legitimate reason to make a change.  Literally all they had to do is use any reason but the one they publicly used, and the AP would have had no recourse.  Here's an imperfect analogy to illustrate.  A company has a 60 year old Director of Finance.  He makes a lot because he's been at the company for a long time, and if he stays until he's 65, they'll have to shell a whole bunch out in pension bonuses.  If they fire him because he's old, it is illegal.  Age is a protected class.  However, if they eliminate the Director of Finance position and let him go and then create a new Financing Manager position at lower pay with mildly different job responsibilities, it is completely legal.  The White House chose literally the only reason they shouldn't have chosen to do what they wanted to do.  Hell, they didn't have to even kick them out. Just leave them and never call on them.  Ever.  There would be no way to prove they were being punished.  Or take their question and just answer "yes," or "no," with zero elaboration.
